article_title: Rosa is a man without a party in District 124
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to ExpressNews.com.

article_metadata.description: During his doomed campaign against Castro, Rosa emphasized his passionate opposition to legalized abortion, blasted the Affordable Care Act, and proudly signed the no-tax-increase pledge created by national conservative advocate Grover Norquist.  [...] it’s a move that reeks of political calculation, but you could probably say the same thing about the breakfast choices of presidential candidates when they make their meticulously spontaneous stops at Iowa diners.  Last Thursday, Rosa, 53, contacted Bexar County Republican Party Chairman Robert Stovall to confirm that he was running in District 124 as a Democrat, and to ask Stovall for access to the GOP’s voter lists.  Texas has a long history of Democrats — such as Rick Perry and Phil Gramm — switching to the GOP, but they were conservative Democrats who moved to a party that more closely matched their philosophy.  Bigley acknowledged the political challenges faced by any Republican in District 124, but pointed out that Nunzio Previtera, a candidate in the recent District 123 special election, maintained his loyalty to the GOP even though he was running in a Democratic stronghold.  The text describes Minjarez, a local attorney, as a “shoo-in for state representative,” and invites female attendees to “join the growing group of women who are coming together and donating the cost of a new pair of shoes to help get Ina elected.”
article_metadata.author.name: By Gilbert Garcia, Metro Columnist
